Title: 2025 Yokosuka Chuo Illumination Photo Contest

Datetime:
- Photo contest entry period: Dec 1, 2025 (Mon) – Jan 31, 2026 (Sat)
- Illumination lighting period: Dec 1, 2025 – Mar 22, 2026
- Lighting hours (illumination): From sunset to 24:00 (midnight)

Place:
- Along Chuo Odori Avenue, Y Deck, and the plaza under Y Deck (Yokosuka-Chuo area)
- Address area: Wakamatsu-cho 2-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa (and surrounding spots)

Detail:
- Take your best winter illumination photo in the Yokosuka-Chuo area and submit it via Instagram.
- How to enter:
- Themes (choose one):
- Nostalgic: #ノスタルジック
- Romantic: #ロマンティック
- Winter Cool: #ウィンタークール
- Everyone can join as long as you agree to the entry rules.

Attention:
- Winners will be contacted by Instagram Direct Message during February 2026, so make sure your account can receive DMs.
- Prizes (approx.):
- Grand Prize: Selectable Domestic Wagyu (catalog gift, about ¥30,000) – 1 winner
- Special Prize: 47CLUB catalog gift (about ¥10,000) – 1 winner per theme
- Honorable Mention: Prizes worth about ¥5,000 – 2 winners per theme
- Please read the contest rules before posting.
- Access: Keikyu “Yokosuka-Chuo” Station (East Exit), about 0–5 minutes on foot.

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/photocon-illumi.html
- Official Instagram: https://instagram.com/yokosukaxmaslights

Tags: Yokosuka, Yokosuka-Chuo, Winter illumination, Photo contest, Instagram, Night view, Kanagawa

Title: Uraga Brick Dry Dock Tour (Guided Tour)

Datetime:
- January 4 (Sun), meet at 09:30 / finish around 11:30 (held in light rain; canceled in severe weather)
- Application deadline: December 22 (Mon)

Place:
- Meeting point: Uraga Dock Main Gate (about a 10-minute walk from Keikyu Line “Uraga” Station)
- Disbanding point: In front of Uraga Community Center
- Address: 4-7 Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A guided walking tour of a historic brick-built dry dock constructed in 1899 (Meiji 32) and closed in 2003 (Heisei 15).
- Learn about the site’s shipbuilding/maintenance history (over 1,000 ships built on the slipway; many repairs and inspections in the dock) and view the dock from multiple angles.
- Course (approx. 1.0 km): briefing → jib crane → dock side → pump house → flap gate → tower crane remains → stairs → dock bottom → stairs → dock head → Uraga Community Center annex (local history museum). (The Brick Dock Utilization Center may be added if available.)

Attention:
- Advance application required (online via the organizer’s site); no postcard applications.
- Capacity: 50 people; lottery if oversubscribed.
- Fee: JPY 500 (elementary school students are free when accompanied by a guardian).
- Bring: drink, rain gear, mask, and any other necessities.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- Transportation and any admission fees are additional.
- Accident compensation is limited to the organizer’s insurance coverage.
- Organizer / inquiries: NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association Office (TEL: 046-822-8256).

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-245.html
- Organizer / application information: http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html

Tags: yokosuka, uraga, guided-tour, history, industrial-heritage, dry-dock, walking-tour

Title: YOKOSUKA Fire Department Parade 2026 (消防出初式)

Datetime:
- Date: 2026-01-11 (Sun)
- Fureai Plaza: 09:30–12:00
- Parade: 10:30–11:11
- Traffic restriction (road closed both directions on Yokosuka Chuo Odori): 09:30–11:30
- Weather note: Cancelled in case of rain

Place:
- Parade route: Yokosuka Chuo Odori (from the National Route 16 side toward Yokosuka-Chuo Station)
- Fureai Plaza: Station-front plaza under the Yokosuka-Chuo Station Y-Deck

Detail:
- A New Year’s fire services parade held on Yokosuka Chuo Odori, featuring marching by the Fire Volunteer Band and Women’s Firefighting Team, plus a parade of fire and rescue vehicles.
- Vehicle parade participants include fire volunteer corps vehicles, Yokosuka City Fire Department vehicles, and U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base fire vehicles.
- Includes a ladder-truck rescue demonstration and other dynamic rescue performances.
- The Fureai Plaza area offers fire vehicle displays, fire volunteer recruitment promotion, and fire prevention/disaster preparedness outreach.

Attention:
- Road closure: Yokosuka Chuo Odori will be closed in both directions from 09:30 to 11:30 (the reopening time may be earlier).
- Viewing from the Y-Deck is not allowed for safety reasons.
- No dedicated parking for the parade—use public transportation.
- Event-day status can be confirmed from 08:00 via the Yokosuka City Call Center (Tel: 046-822-4000).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/syoubou-parade.html
- https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/7410/syoubou/topics/r7pare-do.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Festival, Parade, Fire Department, New Year, Family-friendly, Traffic restriction

Title: Uraga Brick Dry Dock Tour (Guided Tour)

Datetime:
- January 18 (Sunday), 9:30 AM (meet) – around 11:30 AM (dismiss)

Place:
- Meeting point: In front of the Uraga Dock main gate (about a 10-minute walk from Uraga Station on the Keikyu Line)
- Dismissal point: In front of Uraga Community Center (annex)
- Address: 4-7 Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A guided walking tour that lets you experience the history of a brick-built dry dock. The dock was built in 1899 (Meiji 32) and remained in use for shipbuilding and repairs/inspections until its closure in 2003 (Heisei 15).
- Capacity: 50 participants
- Fee: 500 JPY (elementary school students are free if accompanied by a guardian)
- What to bring: drinks, rain gear, a mask, and anything else you may need
- Walking distance: about 1.0 km
- Sample route (highlights): briefing at the meeting point → jib crane → dock side → pump station → flap gate → tower crane remains → stairs → dock bottom → dock head → Uraga Community Center (local history museum)
- Registration: advance application required via the official website (no postcard applications). If applications exceed capacity, participants will be selected by lottery.
- Application deadline: January 5

Attention:
- Transportation costs and any admission fees are not included.
- The event may be canceled in severe weather.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- In case of accidents, compensation is limited to the scope of the organizer’s insurance coverage.
- You can confirm whether the event will be held via the Yokosuka calendar or by calling the Yokosuka City Call Center (7:15–20:00).

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-246.html
- Official site (application / information): http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Uraga, Guided tour, Heritage, Industrial history, Dry dock, Brick architecture, Walking tour, Yokosuka Route Museum

Title: Explore the Uraga Road “Mitori-ezu” Map (Part 4) — Guided Walking Tour

Datetime:
- Saturday, January 31, 2026
- Check-in: 9:00–9:30 (meet at **JR Kinugasa Station**)
- End: around 14:30 (disband at **Keikyu Otsu Station**)
- Cancelled in rain / severe weather

Place:
- Meeting point: **JR Kinugasa Station**, Yokosuka, Kanagawa (Kinugasa Sakaemachi 2-chome 1)
- Disband: **Keikyu Otsu Station**, Yokosuka, Kanagawa
- Route crosses the central Miura Peninsula through cut-throughs and hilly terrain

Detail:
- A guided tour that follows the “Uraga Road Mitori-ezu” route from Kinugasa toward Otsu, enjoying natural scenery and historic landforms.
- Distance: about **7.0 km** (recommended for fairly fit walkers).
- Planned course (in order):
- JR Kinugasa Station → Koshin-ji Temple → “Hoto” Crossroads → Kugō Kōshin-to Stone Monument Group → Kugō Shrine → Sōgen-ji (former site) → Myōshin-ji Temple → Negishi 5-chome Kōshin-to → Tenjinzaka Slope → Aizen Inari Shrine → Otsu Sports Park (lunch) → Otsu Jinya Ruins → Otsu Suwa Shrine → Shinsei-ji Temple → Shinraku-ji Temple → Keikyu Otsu Station

Attention:
- **Advance registration required**; application deadline: **Saturday, January 24**.
- Capacity: **50 people** (lottery if oversubscribed).
- Fee: **500 JPY** (elementary school students are free if accompanied by a guardian).
- Bring: lunch, drink, umbrella, and a ground sheet (plus anything else you may need).
- Transportation costs and any admission fees are **not included**.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- Accident coverage is limited to the scope of the insurance held by the guide association.
- Event status can also be checked via the “Yokosuka Calendar” or Yokosuka City Call Center (046-822-4000, 7:15–20:00).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/4.html
- Application/official tour site: http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Guided walking tour, Uraga Road, Miura Peninsula, Nature scenery, Historic route, Temples and shrines, Hiking (7 km), January 2026

Title: Uraga Road Mitoriezu Walking Tour (Part 5): Toward the Uraga Magistrate’s Office Site

Datetime:
- Sat, Feb 21, 2026
- Check-in starts: 9:00 / Final check-in: 9:30
- Ends: around 14:40 (disband at Konya-cho Bus Stop)
- Weather: postponed in rain to Sat, Feb 28, 2026

Place:
- Meeting point: Keikyu Otsu Station (京急大津駅), Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan
- Address (meeting area): 1-11 Otsu-cho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- A planned guided walking tour (Sports/Outdoor) and the 5th session in the “Tour the Western Uraga Road” series.
- The tour aims for the former Uraga Magistrate’s Office site as the goal.
- Highlights include the historic Yanozu-zaka slope (once considered a difficult pass), a stop at Nishi Kanou Shrine (associated with prayers for the revival/restoration of the Uraga brick dock), and reporting at the Uraga Magistrate’s Office site after completing the route.
- Distance & difficulty: about 4.0 km; suitable for general participants.
- Capacity: 50 participants.
- Fee: 500 JPY (elementary school students accompanied by a guardian are free).
- What to bring: drinks, packed lunch, rain gear, and anything else you may need.

Attention:
- Advance application required. Application deadline: Sat, Feb 14 (year implied: 2026).
- Transportation costs and any admission fees are NOT included and must be paid separately.
- If there are too many applicants, participants will be selected by lottery.
- The tour may be cancelled in rain or severe weather.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- Accident compensation is limited to the insurance coverage held by the Yokosuka City Guide Association.
- After disbanding: from Konya-cho Bus Stop
- To Uraga Station: ~5 minutes, 200 JPY
- To Keikyu Kurihama Station: ~12 minutes, 220 JPY

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-252.html
- Organizer official site: http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html
- Inquiries: NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association Office
- TEL: 046-822-8256 / FAX: 046-827-1682
- Day-of confirmation (hold/cancel):
- Yokosuka Calendar / Yokosuka City Call Center: 046-822-4000 (7:15–20:00)

Tags: Yokosuka, Uraga, Kanagawa, guided tour, walking tour, hiking, historical route, Uraga Brick Dock, Nishi Kanou Shrine, Uraga Magistrate’s Office site

Title: Uraga Brick Dry Dock Tour (Uraga Renga Dock Tour)

Datetime:
- February 15 (Sunday), 09:30 (meet) – around 11:30 (finish)
- Application deadline: February 2 (Monday)

Place:
- Meeting point: Uraga Dock Main Gate (about a 10-minute walk from Uraga Station on the Keikyu Line)
- Finish: In front of Uraga Community Center (Annex / Local History Museum)
- Address: 4-7 Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A guided tour that lets you experience the history of a brick-built dry dock. The dock was constructed in 1899 (Meiji 32) and was used until it closed in 2003 (Heisei 15). While the slipway built more than 1,000 ships, the dock was used for many repairs and inspections. You will view the site from many angles to appreciate its scale and engineering heritage.
- Walking course (about 1.0 km): meeting/orientation → jib crane → dock side wall → pump house → flap gate → tower crane remains → stairs → dock bottom → stairs → dock head → Uraga Community Center (disband). (If available, the Brick Dock Utilization Center may be added.)

Attention:
- Advance registration required (no postcard applications).
- Light rain: tour proceeds. Severe weather: canceled.
- Capacity: 50 people. If there are too many applications, participants will be chosen by lottery.
- Fee: 500 JPY (elementary school children are free if accompanied by a guardian).
- Bring: drinks, rain gear, mask, and anything else you think you may need.
- Wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers). Transportation costs and any admission fees are not included.
- In case of an accident, compensation is limited to the scope of the organizer’s insurance.

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-254.html
- Official site (application): http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html
- Organizer (NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association Office): TEL 046-822-8256 / FAX 046-827-1682
- Day-of status check: Yokosuka Call Center 046-822-2500 (07:15–20:00)

Tags: Yokosuka, Uraga, Guided tour, Industrial heritage, Dry dock, Brick architecture, History walk, Route Museum

Title: Yokosuka Countdown 2026 (よこすかカウントダウン 2026)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-31 (Wed) 18:00 – 2026-01-01 (Thu, Holiday) 01:00

Place:
- Verny Park (Verny Koen), “Ikoi no Hiroba” Square
- Address: 1-1 Shioiri-cho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A New Year’s countdown event at Yokosuka Harbor featuring live stage performances, gourmet food booths, harbor illumination, and fireworks.
- Main highlights:
- Stage event (live music, dance, countdown ceremony)
- Food trucks and tent booths selling local gourmet
- Fireworks launched from the sea (about 500 shots) at midnight
- Illumination of naval vessels and the park to color Yokosuka’s main harbor, plus ship whistles for a Yokosuka-style New Year moment
- Stage timetable (as published):
- 18:00 Shonan Brass Community
- 18:45 Wind Orchestra “Sol-Leone”
- 19:20 Kyokushin Karate Yokosuka Dojo
- 19:45 Dance Studio AMUSE
- 20:30 Ichi-no-I (イチノイー)
- 21:00 Ship illumination / Yokosuka District (JMSDF) HQ building light-up
- 21:10 Kafue Moka (かふぇもか)
- 21:55 Gokuraku Dolce (極楽ドルチェ)
- 22:40 Signarion Ryuseigun (シグナリオン流星群)
- 23:20 Maeda Sara & Family Band
- 23:45 Countdown ceremony
- 00:00 Fireworks launch / ship whistle / searchlight
- 00:05 New Year live
- 00:20 Stage events end
- 01:00 Event ends
- Gourmet & vendor examples listed:
- SUNRISE BERTH, HONCH SHELL, Asian Goyanglidah, Cheese Mocchi in Suzuhihiro, Soba restaurant “Agataya”, STREAM, Restaurant TSUNAMI, South Denim Kitchen, Daddy’s Pizza, and more.

Attention:
- Event content may change or be cancelled without prior notice.
- Check whether the event will be held:
- Yokosuka City Call Center: +81-46-822-4000 (available from 08:00 on Dec 31)
- Event go/no-go: after 08:00
- Fireworks go/no-go: after 13:00
- Access:
- 5 minutes on foot from Keikyu Shioiri Station
- 5 minutes on foot from JR Yokosuka Station
- Parking is limited; please use public transportation when possible.
- The organizers are not responsible for accidents or trouble inside the parking area.
- Keikyu special timetable info is provided via the link below.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/yoksuka-countdown/
- Keikyu special timetable: https://www.keikyu.co.jp/company/news/2025/20251128HP_25140TE.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, New Year, Countdown, Fireworks, Verny Park, Illumination, Food trucks, Live music

Title: Helicopter Sightseeing Flight (Yokosuka)

Datetime:
- February 7 (Sat)–February 8 (Sun), 2026
- Flight operations: 10:00–15:30 (about 15 flights per day; varies by course)
- *New Year Campaign (5% OFF):* December 26 (Fri)–January 4 (Sun) — discount applies only if you complete a booking during this period using the coupon code (announced on Dec 26)

Place:
- Departure/arrival: Uraga City Marina Verasis Heliport, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan
- Reception: Uraga City Marina Verasis, Parking Lot No. 2 (arrive 30 minutes before takeoff)

Detail:
- Scenic helicopter tours departing from/returning to the Uraga City Marina Verasis heliport.
- Routes & standard prices (price is per helicopter):
- Chiyogasaki Battery Ruins → Kannonzaki loop (~10 min): JPY 44,000 / helicopter
- Jogashima loop (~15 min): JPY 66,000 / helicopter
- Enoshima & Kamakura loop (~30 min): JPY 132,000 / helicopter
- Capacity/pricing rule: Up to 3 passengers per helicopter; the price is the same whether 1–3 people ride.
- New Year Campaign discounted prices (5% OFF, when eligible):
- ~10 min course: JPY 41,800 / helicopter
- ~15 min course: JPY 62,700 / helicopter
- ~30 min course: JPY 125,400 / helicopter
- Reservations: Planned to go on sale from 12:00 (noon) on Dec 24 via AirX (AIROS). If seats remain, same-day sales may be available.

Attention:
- Canceled in bad weather.
- You must arrive at the reception area 30 minutes before takeoff.
- Campaign discount requires entering the coupon code at the bottom of the customer-information page and tapping “Apply code” to reflect the discounted amount.

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/helicopter.html
- Booking (AirX / AIROS): https://skyview.airos.jp/caravans/yokosuka

Tags: Yokosuka, Helicopter tour, Uraga, Uraga City Marina Verasis, Kannonzaki, Chiyogasaki Battery Ruins, Jogashima, Enoshima, Kamakura, Scenic flight, New Year campaign

Title: Verny Park Guide Tour (Verny Park / Yokosuka)

Datetime:
- Saturdays from September to December 2025 (17 sessions total)
- Two sessions per day:
- 09:30–10:30 (capacity: 20)
- 11:00–12:00 (capacity: 20)
- Check-in starts 15 minutes before each session

Place:
- Meeting point: In front of the Verny Memorial Museum (Verny Kinenkan), 1-1 Higashi-Hemmi-cho, Yokosuka
- Tour area: Verny Park (Yokosuka)

Detail:
- A 1-hour walking guided tour led by the Yokosuka City Guide Association.
- Theme: the history of Japan’s modernization connected to the former Yokosuka Ironworks/Shipyard, and key figures such as the French engineer Verny and Tadayasu Oguri.
- Typical stops include:
- Verny Memorial Museum
- Battleship “Mutsu” main gun
- Hemmi Hatoba Guard Gate
- Thibodier House
- Oguri & Verny busts
- Price: 500 JPY per person (includes the guided tour + a 1-day “Mikasa Circulation Bus” pass)

Attention:
- Runs in rain; cancelled only in severe weather.
- The entire tour is on foot.
- No refund/exchange if you choose not to use the participant perks.
- Same-day participation may be possible if there is available capacity.
- Participant perks (with the “Mikasa Circulation Bus” 1-day pass):
- Discount for “Mikasa” (one of the world’s three great memorial battleships): 600 JPY → 300 JPY
- 10% off Yokosuka Naval Port Tour and Sarushima ferry routes
- Other Sunday guided courses are also offered (details are available via the booking site).

Link:
- Event page (Yokosuka Tourism Info): https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/verny-guide.html
- Booking / official course page: https://yokosukaguide.webnode.jp/course0booking/

Tags: yokosuka, verny-park, guided-tour, history, modernization, naval-heritage, weekend-event, mikasa

Title: Guided Tour: Explore Miura Clan Historic Sites and Buddhist Statues

Datetime:
- Date: Wednesday, February 4, 2026
- Check-in (reception): 9:00–9:30
- Approx. finish (dismissal): around 14:30
- Note: Cancelled in case of rain/bad weather

Place:
- Meeting point: (Keikyu Bus) Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop (衣笠城址バス停)
- Address (meeting area): 4 Kinugasa-cho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Dismissal point: (Keikyu Bus) Iwato Bus Stop (岩戸バス停)

Detail:
- This is a planned guided walking tour visiting places associated with the Miura clan—often described as one of the largest warrior groups in Sagami Province—who played an important role in the founding era of the Kamakura shogunate.
- You will also visit temples to view nationally important Buddhist statues (Important Cultural Properties) and related historic sites.
- Capacity: 50 people (advance application required)
- Walking distance: about 5.0 km (recommended for strong walkers)
- What to bring: lunch and drinks; other items you may need (example: a walking stick)
- Participation fee: 500 JPY (elementary school students accompanied by a guardian: free)
- Additional temple viewing fees (separate): Daizen-ji 200 JPY, Seiun-ji 200 JPY, Mangan-ji 300 JPY (total 700 JPY)
- Deadline: Wednesday, January 28
- How to apply: From the official site’s top page, select “Tour Application” and apply for the relevant tour.
- Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop → Kinugasa Castle Ruins → Daizen-ji (main hall) → Mansho-ji (Miura Yoshiaki’s grave) → Yakkoji-ato site → Chikadono Shrine → Oyabe Neighborhood Hall (lunch) → Seiun-ji (main hall, Takimi Kannon, graves of three generations of the Miura clan) → Harakiri-matsu Park → Mangan-ji (Kannon & Jizo statues, grave of Sahara Yoshitsura) → Iwato Bus Stop

Attention:
- Transportation and admission/viewing fees are not included (paid separately).
- If there are many applications, participants may be selected by lottery.
- Please wear comfortable, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- In case of an accident, compensation is limited to the scope of the insurance held by the City Guide Association.
- Note: The nationally designated Important Cultural Property statue of Miura Yoshiaki at Mansho-ji is currently under repair and cannot be viewed.
- To the meeting point:
- Yokosuka-Chuo Station Bus Stop → Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop: ~17 min, 280 JPY
- YRP Nobi Station Bus Stop → Kinugasa Castle Ruins Bus Stop: ~18 min, 290 JPY
- After dismissal:
- Iwato Bus Stop → Kita-Kurihama Station Bus Stop: ~10 min, 260 JPY

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-249.html
- Official site (application): http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html
- Contact (NPO Yokosuka City Guide Association Office): TEL +81-46-822-8256
- Yokosuka Call Center (event-day confirmation): +81-46-822-4000 (7:15–20:00)

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Guided tour, Walking tour, Miura clan, Kamakura period, Historic sites, Temples, Buddhist statues, Cultural heritage

Title: Miura Clan Heritage Stamp Rally (Yokosuka City)

Datetime:
- 2025-11-14 (Fri) to 2026-01-04 (Sun)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (23 Miura Clan–related locations across the city)

Detail:
- This is a city-wide stamp rally themed around the Miura clan, a warrior family that supported the founding of the Kamakura shogunate. Participants visit designated “stamp spots” and collect digital stamps using their smartphone’s GPS. After collecting stamps, you can apply for a prize drawing (luxury gifts are mentioned). The route is designed to be explored with a convenient digital map, and representative spots include Manshoji Temple, Manganji Temple, Arasaki Coast (Nagai Castle area), and Arai Castle area.

Attention:
- Participation is free, but you are responsible for smartphone data charges and transportation costs.
- Some “castle” spots are medieval sites; there may be no castle buildings or structures to see at those locations.
- You will need a smartphone with location services (GPS) enabled to obtain stamps.

Link:
- Event page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/miuraitizoku.html
- Official stamp rally info / digital map: https://www.cocoyoko.net/special/miuraichizoku.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Miura clan, Kamakura period, history, stamp rally, digital map, temples, castle ruins

Title: Walk the Narcissus (Daffodil) Road While Viewing the Boso Peninsula (Planned Guide Tour)

Datetime:
- Date: Wednesday, January 14, 2026
- Check-in / Reception: 8:30–9:00 (Meeting point: Keikyu Kurihama Station)
- Estimated finish: Around 12:30 (Disbanding point: Keikyu Nagasawa Station)
- Weather: Cancelled in rain / severe weather
- Application deadline: Wednesday, January 7 (pre-registration required)

Place:
- Meeting point: Keikyu Kurihama Station, 4-4 Kurihama, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Disbanding point: Keikyu Nagasawa Station (Yokosuka City)
- Route (approx. 8.1 km): Keikyu Kurihama Station → Kurihama Tenjin Shrine → Navy Engineering School Monument → Perry Park → Sumiyoshi Shrine → Former Senda Tunnel → Narcissus Road (Biddle Square) → Saiko-ji Temple → Shirahige Shrine → Nobi Coast Promenade → Wakayama Bokusui Couple Tanka Monument → Keikyu Nagasawa Station

Detail:
- Type: Sports / Outdoor, planned guide tour (advance application required)
- Concept: Refresh your mind and body by walking the Narcissus Road and enjoying delicate winter flowers, with views toward the Boso Peninsula across the bay.
- Capacity: 50 people
- What to bring: Drinks, etc.
- Fee: 500 JPY (Elementary school children accompanied by a guardian are free)

Attention:
- Transportation costs and any admission fees are not included and must be paid separately.
- If there are many applications, participants will be selected by lottery.
- The tour will be cancelled in rain or stormy weather.
- Please wear well-broken-in, non-slip shoes (e.g., sneakers).
- In case of an accident, compensation is limited to the scope of the insurance contract held by the City Guide Association.
- Event status can also be checked on the Yokosuka Calendar or via the Yokosuka City Call Center (046-822-4000, 7:15–20:00).

Link:
- Event page (Yokosuka City Tourism Information): https://www.cocoyoko.net/event/post-242.html
- Official site / application: http://yokosuka.kankoh-guide.com/index.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Walking tour, Keikyu Line, Kurihama, Nobi Coast, Winter flowers, Narcissus / Daffodil, Guided tour

Title: Yokosuka Japan Heritage & Uninhabited Island Sarushima Exploration (Planned Guided Tour)

Datetime:

Attention:
- Transportation costs and any entrance fees are not included.

Title: JR Yokosuka Station (JR横須賀駅)

Datetime:
- Retrieved: 2025-12-26 20:33 (as shown on the source page)
- Opened: 1889-06 (opened with the Ōfuna–Yokosuka section of the Yokosuka Line)

Place:
- Address: 1-1 Higashi-Hemmi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0045, Japan
- Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemmi (Yokosuka City)

Detail:
- **Why it’s notable:** JR Yokosuka Station opened in June 1889 as the terminus of the Yokosuka Line and was considered nationally important up to the end of World War II. The current station building (rebuilt in 1940) retains much of the pre-rebuild appearance and has a classic, old-fashioned atmosphere.
- **Architecture & small details to look for:**
- It is known as one of the few stations in Japan without stairs.
- Some platform-roof support columns reuse old rails stamped “1886.”
- **Walking idea:** The station is positioned as a start/end point of Yokosuka’s “Umikaze no Michi” promenade (a sea-and-green 10,000-meter route).
- **Parking:** None.
- **Accessibility (barrier-free):**
- Elevators: No
- Escalators: No
- Step-free entrance measures (including ramps): Yes
- Wheelchair-accessible toilet: Yes
- Ostomate-accessible toilet: Yes
- Wheelchair rental: No
- Baby diaper-changing sheet: No (however, a simple bed is available and can be used for diaper changing)
- Accessible parking for people with disabilities: No
- Tactile guidance blocks: Yes
- Other: Braille fare table, baby chair, simple bed

Attention:
- There are **no elevators or escalators**, so plan routes and transfers accordingly.
- **No parking** at the station.
- Baby facilities are limited; diaper-changing is possible using the provided simple bed.
- For train times/fares or lost-and-found, contact JR East’s inquiry center (as listed on the source page).

Link:
- Official spot page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/yokosuka-st.html
- Related nearby spots listed on the source page: Verny Park, Verny Memorial Museum, Nanakama Tunnel (JR Taura Station), Thibaudier House (Yokosuka Modern Heritage Museum)

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, jr, yokosuka-line, railway-heritage, historic-architecture, barrier-free, promenade

Title: Yokosuka Genic Street (YOKOSUKA GENIC STREET)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:44 (captured from the official tourism page)

Place:
- Yokosuka East Coast (Shiioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemmi area), Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A public-art project that revitalizes monuments along Yokosuka’s coastal street with newly created artworks, aiming to improve the streetscape and create a lively, walkable waterfront.
- In addition to wall art and monument art, events such as the “Yokosuka Coast Performance” (music/dance) are held to generate new vibrancy along the coast.
- Photo tip: Share your memories by posting photos taken here with the hashtag **#Sukageni** (Japanese: **#スカジェニ**).
- Notable artworks / areas:
- **First artwork (completed Nov 2020):** A 50-meter wave-shaped wall fountain monument redesigned by professional artists with the theme “LOVE,” designed as a photogenic spot.
- **SUKAGENI POP:** Selected from 23 public submissions; created by Ayumu Kusayama with the theme “Heart-thrilling Yokosuka.” Features a playful monument with a circular hole and pop motifs that may include “deep local references.” Located near Umikaze Park.
- **SUKAGENI MIX:** Created by Kanto Gakuin University Art Club students; eight wall panels featuring warm, hand-painted textures and vivid colors.
- **SUKAGENI LIFE:** Eight wall panels selected from about 80 works by users of local welfare facilities, themed around “Life,” “Pop,” and diversity.
- **SUKAGENI × LEEGET:** Artist LEEGET transformed the wall of a public toilet along the coast into a pop wall-art piece. (Wheelchair-accessible toilet available at this location.)
- Access (walk):
- ~15 minutes from **Keikyu Yokosuka-Chuo Station**
- ~20 minutes from **Keikyu Kenritsu-Daigaku Station**
- Parking: None

Attention:
- Please do NOT use flash, drones, or similar filming equipment.
- Avoid actions that could damage the artwork (e.g., extreme close-ups that may cause contact or wear).
- Commercial photography is not permitted.
- When posting publicly, be careful about including other visitors in your photos.
- The city is not responsible for troubles between visitors or with passersby.
- The artworks are located along sidewalks—do not block pedestrian traffic while taking photos.
- Do not litter.
- Do not damage wall art, plantings, or related facilities.

Link:
- Official tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/sukageni.html
- City project page (related): https://www.city.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/0810/10000me-toru.html
- Artist (LEEGET): https://www.instagram.com/leeget/  /  https://twitter.com/LEEGET
- Instagram (Yokosuka East Coast): https://www.instagram.com/yokosuka_higashikaigan/
- YouTube (related videos):
- https://youtu.be/JK1uy77_x8c
- https://youtu.be/r9eCZkFNZQ0

Tags: Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan, Public art, Street art, Waterfront, Photo spot, Walking, Umikaze Park, Accessibility (limited)

Title: YOKOSUKA Naval Port Cruise (YOKOSUKA Gunkō Meguri)

Datetime:
- Operating days: Runs daily (service may be canceled due to sea conditions or other special circumstances).
- Departure times: 10:00 (irregular extra service; check the website), 11:00, 12:00, 13:00, 14:00, 15:00
- Duration: About 45 minutes for one loop around the harbor.

Place:
- Boarding pier: Shiioiri Pier (behind “Coaska Bayside Stores”), Honcho 3-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Car navigation note (address input): 2-1-12 Honcho, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Nearest stations:
- Keikyu Line: Shiioiri Station (about 5 minutes on foot)
- JR: Yokosuka Station (about 10 minutes on foot)

Detail:
- A harbor cruise where you can see many ships up close in Yokosuka Main Port and Nagaura Port, which are used by the U.S. Navy and the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force.
- The course departs from the pier behind Coaska Bayside Stores and makes a full loop through Yokosuka Main Port, Nagaura Port, and the Arai-bori canal/waterway.
- Enjoy Yokosuka’s historic “naval port city” atmosphere from the sea (Yokosuka developed as a naval port from the late Edo period).

Attention:
- Price (standard): JPY 2,200 (elementary school children: JPY 1,100). Prices may vary by day/season.
- Children: One preschool child rides free per paying adult; if the number of preschool children exceeds the number of adults, the excess is charged at the child rate.
- Yokosuka resident discount: Eligible visitors should present an ID showing their address at the ticket counter.
- Reservations: Accepted up to 6 months in advance by phone or via the operator’s website. Same-day tickets may be sold at the pier if seats are available.
- Recommended: Reserve by the day before, as it can get crowded.
- Parking: Use nearby paid parking (e.g., Coaska Bayside Stores parking, Baysquare Parking, or Verny Park parking).
- Accessibility (highlights):

Title: Umikaze Park (Yokosuka) — Seaside Lawn, BBQ, and Action Sports

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 19:22 (JST)  *(timestamp shown in the source report)*

Place:
- Umikaze Park, Heisei-cho 3-23, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi

Detail:
- **What it is:** A spacious seaside park with a large lawn where you can relax and look out over Tokyo Bay—**Sarushima Island** floats right offshore.
- **BBQ by the sea:** You can enjoy barbecue while watching the ocean. A paid service, **“Umikaze BBQ,”** offers equipment rental and support (carry/clean-up and trash collection).
- **Action-sports & courts:** Areas for **skateboarding**, **3-on-3 basketball**, **mountain biking**, and **wall tennis**.
- **Family-friendly zones:**
- *Shinsui Seawall*: A waterside area designed for casual sea contact—kids and adults get excited spotting fish and crabs (collection is prohibited).
- *Water Hill*: Flowing water and a fountain/pond area that becomes a fun play spot in summer.
- *Playground Area*: Great for toddlers; toilets nearby.
- *Flowerbed Plaza*: European-style flowerbeds with seasonal blooms and a circular bed with a calmer atmosphere.
- **Scenic walk:** The “**10,000m Promenade**” is an approximately 10 km seaside walking route that continues toward the boardwalk/Kannonzaki area, with bay views (Sarushima, sea forts, Yokohama landmarks, Bay Bridge, Aqua-Line, and the Boso Peninsula).
- **History nearby:** The **Third Sea Fort** (built for Tokyo Bay defense) was constructed from 1890 (Meiji 23) over ~30 years, completed in 1921 (Taisho 10), then largely collapsed/submerged after the 1923 Great Kanto Earthquake. A large barracks structure salvaged during removal work was relocated to Umikaze Park and has been permanently exhibited as a civil engineering heritage item since **2006-03-01**.
- **Basic info:**
- Admission: **Free**
- Closed: **None**
- Access: About **15 minutes on foot** from **Keikyu Kenritsu-Daigaku Station**
- Parking: Regular **182** spaces + Large vehicles **2** spaces (paid; rates vary by time and vehicle type)
- Contact: **046-826-2899** (management office)

Attention:
- **Fountain operating limits (summer):** Due to summer electricity-saving measures, the fountain runs **only on weekends and holidays from July to September**.
- **BBQ rules:** Use a grill/stove (no open flame on the grass). Do not barbecue on paths or planted areas. Take all trash home (including ash/charcoal), and do not wash greasy grates/plates in drains.
- **Nature protection:** **Collecting living creatures is prohibited** in the waterside area.
- **Drones:** **Drone use is not permitted** in the park.
- **Barrier-free notes:** Slopes are available for entrance steps; accessible toilets and diaper-changing sheets exist, and there are designated parking spaces (4). Elevators/escalators and wheelchair rental are not available.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page (spot page): https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/umikaze-park.html
- Official park site: https://www.kanagawaparks.com/umikaze/
- Umikaze BBQ (service page): https://digiq.jp/portal/experience/73735/0

Title: Yokosuka Iris Garden (Shobu-en / しょうぶ園)

- Closed:

Place:

Detail:

Title: Yokosuka Modern Heritage Museum Thibaudier Residence

Datetime:
- Regular hours: 09:00–17:00 (open daily; no regular closing day).
- Year-end special opening: Open until 25:00 on Dec 31, 2025 for “Yokosuka Countdown 2026”; closed on Jan 1.
- Theater schedule note: From Jan 9, 2026, the 16:00 screening starts at 16:15.

Place:
- Address: 1-1 Shioiri-cho, Yokosuka City (inside Verny Park), Kanagawa, Japan.
- Area: Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi.
- Access: ~5 minutes on foot from JR Yokosuka Station; ~5 minutes on foot from Keikyu Shioiri Station.

Detail:
- A reconstructed Western-style residence originally built around 1869 as official housing for Jules César Claude Thibaudier, a French engineer (deputy head) at the Yokosuka Ironworks—considered one of the oldest Western-style buildings of its class on Honshu.
- Inside, visitors can see relocated original structural elements such as the wooden-frame brick wall and truss components, alongside exhibits introducing Yokosuka’s modernization history.
- The facility also serves as a hub for the “Yokosuka Route Museum,” which connects citywide historical, cultural, and nature “satellite” spots through themed routes.
- Optional theater experience: A guided 3D-CG, hands-on movie experience (approx. 15 minutes) with rotating themes (e.g., “Black Ships Arrival”).

Attention:
- Admission: Free (some paid content available).
- Theater fee: 200 JPY; free for high school students and younger. Screenings are typically twice per hour (at :00 and :30); reservations recommended if seats are limited.
- Barrier-free notes: No elevator or escalator; ramp measures for entrance steps are available; wheelchair-accessible toilet is available; wheelchair rental is not available.

Link:
- Official site: http://thibaudier-yokosuka.com/
- Reservation (theater): https://airrsv.net/yokosuka-thibaudier/calendar
- Source page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/Thibaudier.html

Title: Perry Park (Kurihama, Yokosuka) — Landing Site of Commodore Matthew C. Perry

Datetime:
- Best time to visit: Year-round (closed on Mondays; the day after a public holiday; and Dec 29–Jan 3).
- Historical date: July 14, 1853 (Perry landed at Kurihama Beach; commemorated by the Landing Monument).

Place:
- Perry Park (Perry Kōen), Kurihama, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Address: 7-14 Kurihama, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0831

Detail:
- **Why it’s worth visiting:** Perry Park marks the moment Japan’s “opening to the world” accelerated. Inside the park stands the **Perry Landing Monument**, built to commemorate Commodore **Matthew Calbraith Perry** landing at Kurihama Beach on July 14, 1853 and delivering the U.S. President’s letter requesting Japan to open the country.
- **What to see:**
- **Perry Landing Monument** (the monument’s inscription is attributed to the calligraphy of **Hirobumi Ito**).
- **Perry Memorial Museum** (inside the park): exhibits historical materials and models related to Perry’s arrival.
- **Jōkisen Monument**: a witty poem/pun comparing the shock of “four cups of tea that keep you awake” with the shock of “four steamships arriving,” capturing how startling the “Black Ships” appeared to people at the time.
- **Scenery note:** The coastline once had a well-known beach; later land reclamation and industrial development changed the shoreline. From the remaining sandy area, you can still see the **Tokyo Wan Ferry** route and large industrial structures offshore.

Attention:
- **Admission:** Free.
- **Access (public transport):** From **Keikyū Kurihama Station**, take a bus bound for **Nobi Kaigan** (~10 minutes) and get off at **“Perry Kinenhi”** bus stop.
- **Parking:** None.
- **Accessibility (summary):** No elevator/escalator; slope measures at the entrance are available, but wheelchair-accessible toilets and several other barrier-free facilities are not available.
- **Rules:** Use of drones and similar devices is **not permitted** in the park.
- **Contact:** Perry Memorial Museum +81-46-834-7531

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/perry-park.html
- Official park site: http://www.kanagawaparks.com/kurihama-perry/perry/

Tags: Yokosuka, Kurihama, Perry Park, Japanese history, Black Ships, Monument, Museum, Waterfront walk

Title: Verny Commemorative Museum (Verny Kinenkan), Yokosuka

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:45 (JST)  *(report capture time)*

Place:
- Verny Commemorative Museum, Verny Park area, Yokosuka (Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi)
- Address: 1-1 Higashi-Hemmi-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0045, Japan
- Access: 1 minute on foot from JR Yokosuka Station; about 10 minutes on foot from Keikyu “Shioiri” Station

Detail:
- The Verny Commemorative Museum was built to preserve and share the achievements of the French engineer François Léonce Verny, who helped create the Yokosuka Iron Works—often described as a starting point of Japan’s modernization.
- The museum sits in a corner of Verny Park, looking across the water toward the former iron works site (now the U.S. Navy Yokosuka Base).
- The exterior design features a steep roof and stone walls inspired by traditional homes in Brittany, France (Verny’s home region).
- Highlights inside include two steam hammers installed at the Yokosuka Iron Works under Verny’s direction. They are considered the oldest surviving steam hammers in Japan and are designated as Important Cultural Properties.
- Both steam hammers were manufactured in 1865, imported from the Netherlands the following year, and reportedly operated for more than 100 years making parts such as ship components.
- Additional exhibits include:
- A 1/10 scale model recreating the 3-ton steam hammer as it appeared during its final operation period
- A hands-on device to experience Pascal’s principle
- Video exhibits recreating the late-Edo/Meiji-era Yokosuka Iron Works with 3D computer graphics
- Video programs introducing the steam hammers and Yokosuka’s modern industrial heritage
- Reference books, and sales of original goods and selected history-related publications

Attention:
- Admission: Free
- Hours: 09:00–17:00
- Closed: Mondays (if Monday is a public holiday, closed the following day) and during the year-end/New Year period
- Parking: None
- Accessibility (summary):
- No elevator/escalator; no entrance ramp/slope measures indicated
- Wheelchair rental: Available
- Wheelchair-accessible toilet / ostomate toilet: Not available
- Tactile guiding blocks: Available
- If you need step-free access, check the published barrier-free route information before visiting

Link:
- Tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/verny.html
- Official site: https://www.museum.yokosuka.kanagawa.jp/satellite-facilities/verney

Tags: yokosuka, museum, industrial-heritage, history, verny, steam-hammer, verny-park, free-admission

Title: Shikkama Tunnels (JR Taura Station)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:31 (source page capture time)

Place:
- JR Taura Station (Yokosuka Line), Taura-cho 1-6, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (inside the station premises)

Detail:
- JR Taura Station is famous for its unusually short platform (about 200 m). With 11-car trains, some cars stop inside a tunnel, so certain doors do not open.
- On the Yokosuka Station side of JR Taura Station, three adjacent tunnels from three eras can be seen from the station overpass: the oldest (down line) completed in 1889 (Meiji era), a brick-built tunnel added in 1924 (Taisho era) for double-tracking, and the largest tunnel built in 1943 (Showa era) for wartime military freight.
- The area name is historically “Shikkama” (literally “lost sickle”), and the tunnel name is said to use the homophone “Shikkama” written as “Shikkama / Shikkama (Seven Kettles)” to avoid the unlucky association of “losing a boiler (kama)” for steam locomotives.

Attention:
- No parking is available.
- Accessibility support is very limited (e.g., no elevators/escalators; wheelchair-accessible toilet and other related facilities are not available).
- When boarding/alighting, follow station guidance because some doors may remain closed due to the short platform.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/taura-st.html

Tags: yokosuka, taura, railway, tunnel, history, architecture, meiji, taisho, showa, trainspotting

Title: Mt. Miurafuji (Miura Fuji) — Panoramic View Hike in Yokosuka

Datetime:
- Information retrieved: 2025-12-26 20:41 (JST)

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area)
- Access: About 60 minutes on foot from Keikyu Nagasawa Station
- Parking: None
- Contact: Yokosuka City Tourist Information Office (+81-46-822-8301, 09:30–17:00)

Detail:
- Mt. Miurafuji is not a very high mountain, but the summit offers wide-open views. On clear days, you can see from Sagami Bay all the way to Tokyo Bay, and even Izu Oshima and the Boso Peninsula.
- With good luck, you may also spot Mt. Fuji appearing grandly above Mt. Takeyama.
- From the summit area, you can overlook the full view of “Hikari-no-Oka” at YRP (Yokosuka Research Park), a cluster of mobile communications R&D institutes.
- A hiking route is maintained that links Tsukuihama → Mt. Miurafuji → Hodaiyama → Mt. Takeyama.
- Cultural note: A Sengen Shrine (Oku-miya) is enshrined at the summit, with a stone monument carved “Sengen Shrine Oku-miya.” Historically, fishermen used Mt. Miurafuji and Mt. Takeyama as landmarks to locate fishing grounds and identify the direction back to port, connecting the mountain to faith in big catches and maritime safety.

Attention:
- Water facilities are available at the Mt. Takeyama summit toilet (not necessarily at Mt. Miurafuji itself).
- No parking is available—public transportation is recommended.
- Accessibility: The site is not barrier-free (no elevators/escalators/ramps; no wheelchair-accessible toilet; no wheelchair rental; no diaper-changing or universal sheet; no accessible parking; no guiding blocks).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/miurafuzi.html

Title: Memorial Ship MIKASA (One of the “World’s Three Great Memorial Ships”)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:06 (JST) — captured from Yokosuka City Tourism Information page timestamp

Place:
- Memorial Ship MIKASA (inside Mikasa Park)
- 82-19 Inaoka-cho, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 238-0003, Japan (Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi area)

Detail:
- **Why it’s special:** Mikasa is a steel battleship built in **1902** in the United Kingdom and is known as the **flagship of Japan’s Combined Fleet** under Admiral **Heihachiro Togo** during the **Russo-Japanese War**. It is described as the **world’s oldest surviving steel battleship** and is recognized as a component cultural property of **Japan Heritage**.
- **Historical highlights:** After retiring from service (1923), Mikasa was preserved in Yokosuka as a memorial ship (1926). Following WWII, parts such as the guns, masts, and bridge were removed by order of the occupation forces, but the ship was later restored to its current form in **1961** with donations and support including from the U.S. Navy.
- **What to see onboard:** Exhibits include Imperial Japanese Navy uniforms/equipment, Russo-Japanese War materials, and restored rooms (e.g., the Commander-in-Chief’s room, Chief of Staff room, Captain’s room). At the conning tower, footprints mark the spot where Admiral Togo is said to have stood for five hours during the Battle of the Sea of Japan.
- **Key ship specs (quick facts):** Displacement 15,140 tons; length 132 m; beam 23 m; speed 18 knots; crew 860; main guns 4 × 30 cm; secondary 14 × 15 cm; 20 × 8 cm; 4 × 45 cm torpedo tubes.
- **Admission:** 600 JPY (adults), 300 JPY (high school students), free (elementary & junior high students).
- **Opening hours:**
- Apr–Sep: 09:00–17:30
- Mar & Oct: 09:00–17:00
- Nov–Feb: 09:00–16:30
- **Closed:** Dec 28–31
- **Access:**
- From Keikyu **Yokosuka-Chuo Station**: ~15 min on foot, or take the Mikasa loop bus and get off at “Mikasa Park.”
- From JR **Yokosuka Station**: take a bus toward Yokosuka-Chuo area (~10 min), get off at “Otaki-cho,” then ~7 min walk.
- By car: from Yokohama-Yokosuka Road **Yokosuka IC**, follow Prefectural Route 28 to Route 16, then turn left at the Mikasa Park entrance.
- **Parking (Mikasa Park parking, 42 spaces):** 410 JPY up to 1 hour; +210 JPY per 30 minutes up to 2 hours; after 2 hours, 830 JPY plus +100 JPY per additional hour (up to 1 hour increments).

Attention:
- **Accessibility notes (important):**
- No elevator / no escalator.
- Step-free entry measures (including a slope/ramp) are available.
- Wheelchair rental is available, but **wheelchair users must enter via the forward entrance on the middle deck (1F)** and **cannot move to the upper deck (2F)**.
- Wheelchair-accessible toilets are **not available** (also no ostomate-ready toilets, no baby diaper-changing sheet, and no adult universal changing sheet).
- **Plan around closures:** The ship is **closed Dec 28–31**, so avoid year-end dates.
- **Crowd/comfort tip:** Winter hours end earlier (16:30), so arrive with enough time if visiting Nov–Feb.

Link:
- Yokosuka City Tourism Info: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/mikasa.html
- Official site: http://www.kinenkan-mikasa.or.jp/

Title: Jyusan Pass (十三峠 / Jyusan Pass)

Datetime:
- Historical context: 1720 (Kyōhō 5) onward, when travel between Edo and Uraga increased; later referenced in 1812; associated with late-Edo ukiyo-e artist Utagawa Hiroshige.
- Source page capture timestamp: 2025-12-26 20:35 (as shown in the report).

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan — Shioiri / Yokosuka-Chuo / Hemi area.
- Along the former “East Uraga Road” (Higashi no Uraga-michi), near Ota-zaka by Chōzen-ji, continuing on the ridge toward Anjin-zuka.

Detail:
- A historically steep and demanding mountain path on the “East Uraga Road,” said to have been the biggest bottleneck on the Uraga route for travelers and local villagers.
- Name origin traditions include: “the 13th pass from Hodogaya,” or being connected to a place of worship related to the “Thirteen Buddhas,” among other local theories.
- Scenic viewpoint: on clear days, you can see as far as Yokohama Landmark Tower, Nagaura Bay, and the factory groups of the Chiba coastal industrial zone.
- Cultural note: Hiroshige is said to have been struck by the panoramic view here and reportedly depicted it in his travel sketch diary (“Hiroshige Busō Meisho Tabi Enikki”).

Attention:
- Parking: none.
- Barrier-free facilities are not available (no elevators/escalators/ramps; no wheelchair-accessible toilet; no ostomate toilet; no wheelchair rental; no diaper-changing or universal seat; no designated accessible parking; no guidance blocks).
- Although the old road is now a paved road open to cars, the area is historically steep—wear appropriate shoes and be cautious in bad weather.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/13touge.html

- 6-5-1 Nishi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0824, Japan (Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga area)

Detail:
- Chiyogasaki Gun Battery is a Western-style coastal artillery fort built by the Imperial Japanese Army between 1892 and 1895, next to the earlier “Hironeyama Daiba” (Hironeyama Battery) remains that were constructed by the Aizu Domain in the late Edo period.
- The site sits on a hill (about 65 m above sea level) with three north–south gun emplacements. Each emplacement originally held two howitzers.
- The emplacements are bowl-shaped, and underground you can still see brick-walled, concrete-ceilinged protected rooms (bombproof shelters) and ammunition magazines.
- Surviving features include a shell-hoist shaft used to supply shells to the guns and an internal water supply/drainage system.
- Because it preserves its original construction well and is important for understanding modern Japanese military and fortification technology, the site was designated a National Historic Site in 2015. It is also recognized as a component cultural asset of Japan Heritage.

Attention:
- Opening days: Saturdays, Sundays, and Japanese public holidays (closed Dec 29–Jan 3).
- Opening hours:
- Oct–Feb: 09:30–15:30 (last entry 15:00)
- Mar–Sep: 09:30–16:30 (last entry 16:00)
- Temporary closure may occur during severe weather (heavy rain, flooding, strong winds), typhoons, snowfall, or other unsafe conditions.
- No vehicles (including bicycles and motorbikes) may enter or park inside the site. Use nearby parking areas (including paid parking) and walk in.
- Accessibility: Barrier-free facilities are not provided (e.g., no elevator/escalator, no step-free entrance measures, and no wheelchair-accessible restroom).

Title: Koumi-ishi Stone (子産石)

- Near the “Koumi-ishi (子産石)” bus stop

Detail:
- Koumi-ishi (literally “child-bearing stone”) is a stone long revered as a symbol of fertility and safe childbirth.
- A historical record known as *Miura Kokyuroku* mentions a “Koumi-ishi” at Kuruwa-no-hama, describing how the stone “produces” or “splits off” stones over the years—hence the name.
- Local traditions say that women hoping to conceive would rub the stone and then rub their abdomen with the same hand, and that pregnant women may rub their belly with the stone to pray for an easy delivery.
- A representative Koumi-ishi stone (about 1 meter in diameter) located near the bus stop has been designated as a municipal cultural asset (citizen cultural heritage).

Attention:
- No parking is available.
- Accessibility: the site listing indicates no elevator/escalator, no ramps/step-free entrance measures, and no wheelchair-accessible toilets or other universal facilities. Plan accordingly, especially if visiting with a stroller or wheelchair.
- Access is primarily by bus from Keikyu Zushi–Hayama Station.

Title: Nuta Castle Remains (怒田城址)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:39 (timestamp shown on the source report)

Place:
- Around Yoshii 1-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (walkable from Keikyu Kurihama Station / JR Kurihama Station)

Detail:
- **What it is:** The remains of *Nuta Castle*, believed to have been built by the Miura clan, a powerful warrior family known for active maritime operations on the Miura Peninsula.
- **Historical context:** During the Kinugasa battle, Wada Yoshimori is said to have argued for fighting from the well-fortified Nuta Castle, but Miura Ōsuke Yoshiaki chose Kinugasa Castle instead. Tradition holds that, as Kinugasa Castle neared collapse, members of the Miura clan escaped via a back route to this area, then sailed toward Awa (Bōsō Peninsula). The toponym **“Funakura”** (“boat storehouse/harbor”) remains as a trace of where boats were hidden or moored.
- **Fortification & terrain:** The castle reportedly took advantage of natural landforms—described as steep and difficult to approach on three sides, with a single route opening toward the sea—making it a highly defensible position.
- **Archaeology & designation:** Today the area is protected as a Kanagawa Prefecture–designated historic site, **“Ruins centered on the Yoshii Shell Midden.”** Excavations identified multiple shell-midden locations and settlement traces spanning the Jōmon period and later eras, with the broader plateau also considered the likely location of the late-Heian mountain castle.

Attention:
- **No parking** on site.
- **Access:** About a **20-minute walk** from **Keikyu Kurihama Station** or **JR Kurihama Station**.
- **Barrier-free:** Facilities are largely unavailable (no elevator/escalator/ramps; no accessible toilet; no wheelchair rental; no diaper-changing/universal sheet; no designated accessible parking; no tactile guidance blocks).
- As an archaeological/historic area, please respect signs, surrounding residences, and the landscape.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/nutazyoushi.html
- Yokosuka Tourist Information Center (09:30–17:00): +81-46-822-8301

- Atagoyama Park is the oldest park in Yokosuka, opened in 1891. It was developed as a park when a memorial (spirit-inviting monument) was built for Saburosuke Nakajima, a Uraga magistrate’s officer involved in negotiations during Commodore Perry’s arrival at Uraga.

Title: East Kano Shrine (Higashi Kano Jinja)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 20:40 JST (timestamp shown on the source page capture)

Place:
- East Kano Shrine, 2-21-25 Higashi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0821, Japan

Detail:
- East Kano Shrine stands on the eastern side of Uraga Harbor, facing West Kano Shrine across the water.
- A well behind the shrine is linked to a local legend: Kaishū Katsu is said to have performed water purification there before the Kanrin Maru’s Pacific crossing, and then fasted on the summit of nearby Myojin-yama.
- The guardian lion-dogs (komainu) in front of the worship hall are unusual: each holds a pup, and the right one appears to be nursing; both seem to have closed mouths, creating a “pair across the harbor” story with the West shrine’s komainu.
- The shrine is popular as a “wish-granting” (kano = “to come true”) power spot. A local custom mentioned in the guide is to place a magatama charm from West Kano Shrine inside a protective pouch from East Kano Shrine to support good relationships (including romance).
- Historically, the enshrined deity is Emperor Ōjin (the same as Iwashimizu Hachimangū in Kyoto). The shrine is said to have begun on August 15, 1181, when the monk Mongaku invited the spirit of Iwashimizu Hachimangū while praying for the revival of the Genji; later, Minamoto no Yoritomo’s success led to the name “Kano Daimyōjin.”
- The wooded hill behind the shrine is Myojin-yama (about 50 meters high). It has an inner shrine (okumiya) near the summit and a marker for “Kaishū Katsu’s fasting place.”
- The Myojin-yama area is valued for its well-preserved natural forest and biodiversity; the ubamegashi (Quercus phillyraeoides) here is noted as a northern distribution limit in the prefecture. The grove is designated as a Prefectural Natural Monument (“Kano Shrine Shaso-rin”).

Attention:
- Accessibility: the site lists no elevator/escalator and no ramp/slope measures, and indicates that the route from the “Shinmachi” bus stop includes stairs.
- Parking is limited to 10 cars.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/higashi-kanou-z.html

Title: Yokosuka Cycling: Routes, Share Bikes, and Rider Support

Datetime:

Place:
- Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- Yokosuka City is a popular cycling destination that can be reached from central Tokyo in about one hour. Riders can enjoy a mix of nature and urban scenery, with varied roads that make for a dynamic ride.
- Food is also part of the experience: Yokosuka highlights fresh seafood and local mountain produce, making it easy to plan a ride around meals.
- The official **Yokosuka City Cycling Map** introduces three main courses:
- **“Gurutto Skychi!” (68 km)** — a longer loop to cover many highlights.
- **East Coast Route (26 km)**
- **West Coast Route (23 km)**
- If you run into trouble while riding, Yokosuka partners with the local taxi association to offer a paid support service called **“CYCLE RESCUE TAXI YOKOSUKA”**, which can transport both rider and bicycle safely to a destination such as your home or a station.
- For short-distance sightseeing, Yokosuka also offers **electric-assist share cycles**. You can pick up and return bikes at different stations (one-way drop-off), and the service is usable via smartphone through **HELLO CYCLING** (external site). A call center is available for support.

Attention:
- **Cycle Rescue Taxi is a paid service.** Keep the taxi company phone numbers handy in case of emergencies.
- Share-cycle support: **HELLO CYCLING Call Center: 050-3821-8282**.
- Follow Japan’s bicycle safety principles:
- Roads are the default (sidewalks are exceptions).
- Keep left on the roadway.
- On sidewalks, prioritize pedestrians and ride slowly near the roadway side.
- Obey rules: no drunk riding, no doubling, no riding side-by-side; use lights at night; stop and check safety at intersections.
- Children should wear helmets.
- Avoid riding in large groups, and share the road thoughtfully with pedestrians, cyclists, and cars.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/special/cycling.html

- Yokosuka-specific performances are held annually, such as “Yokosuka Jazz Dreams” and events featuring the U.S. Navy 7th Fleet Band.

Title: Mt. Takeyama (Takeyama) — Yokosuka, Miura Peninsula

Datetime:
- Best season: mid-April to early May (azaleas bloom around this period).
- Annual events:
- Jan 28: “Hatsu-Fudo” (first Fudo day) — the principal image of Fudo Myo-o is opened to the public.
- May 3–5 (typical): Takeyama Azalea Festival (Takeyama Tsutsuji Matsuri).

Place:
- Mt. Takeyama, Take 1-chome, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area).
- Elevation: about 200 m.
- Viewpoint: panoramic views of Tokyo Bay and Sagami Bay; on clear days you may see Mt. Fuji.

Detail:
- Mt. Takeyama is a popular nature spot known for its azaleas (about 1,200 shrubs planted near the summit).
- A hiking route is maintained connecting Mt. Takeyama to nearby peaks such as Hodaiyama (Battery Hill) and Miura Fuji.
- Near the summit you can visit Takeyama Fudo-in (Ryuzukasan Jikyoji Takeyama Fudo-in), the first site of the Miura Peninsula pilgrimage.
- During azalea season, the summit area becomes especially scenic; some azaleas grow tall enough to form a “red tunnel,” making it a good place for a picnic.

Attention:
- No parking available.
- Access includes a bus + a long walk:
- From Keikyu Yokosuka-Chuo Station or JR Yokosuka Station: take a bus bound for the Nagai area (e.g., “Nagai,” “Misakiguchi,” etc.), get off at “Ikizuka,” then walk about 40 minutes.
- From Keikyu YRP Nobi Station: take the “Shimin Byoin” (City Hospital) bus, get off at “Ikizuka,” then walk about 40 minutes.
- Barrier-free notes (as listed):
- No elevator / escalator / slope measures at entrances.
- No wheelchair-accessible toilets, ostomate toilets, wheelchair rental, diaper-changing facilities, or accessible parking.

Title: Takeyama Fudoin Temple (Takeyama Fudo)

Datetime:
- Annual events: January 28 (Hatsufudo / first Fudo day, principal image 공개 viewing); late April to May (Takeyama Azalea Festival / Tsutsuji Matsuri)

Place:
- Takeyama area, Yokosuka City (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama)
- Address: 1-3040 Take, Yokosuka, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- A mountaintop temple dedicated to Fudo Myoo (Acala), revered locally as “Namikiri Fudo” for maritime safety. It has long been worshiped by fishermen and seafarers as a protector for safe voyages and good catches.
- The approach routes spread in multiple directions, and “Mae-Fudo” statues (Fudo Myoo images) stand near trailheads as guides for visitors.
- Around the summit, roughly 2,000 azaleas bloom, and the Takeyama Azalea Festival is held each spring.
- A hiking network connects Mt. Takeyama with nearby peaks such as Hotaiyama and Miura Fuji.
- From the rooftop observatory amid the azaleas, you can enjoy wide views over Tokyo Bay and the Boso Peninsula; on clear days you may see Izu Oshima, the Izu Peninsula across Sagami Bay, and Mt. Fuji. The viewpoint is recognized in the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism’s “Kanto Fujimi 100 Views.”

Attention:
- No parking is available.
- From the bus stop, expect about a 40-minute walk to reach the temple.
- Barrier-free facilities are generally not available (elevators/escalators/accessible toilets, etc.). Contact the temple in advance if you need assistance.

Title: Uraga no Watashi (Ferryboat) — “Ponpon Boat” in Uraga, Yokosuka

Datetime:
- Accessed: 2025-12-26 19:34 (JST)

Place:
- Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
- Ferry terminals:
- East Pier: Higashi-Uraga 2-19-10 (nearby)
- West Pier: Nishi-Uraga 1-2-19 (nearby)

Detail:
- A small local ferry affectionately nicknamed the “Ponpon Boat,” and a symbol of Uraga. It is a practical way for residents and visitors to move between the east and west sides of Uraga, separated by the harbor.
- There is no fixed timetable: when the boat is on the opposite bank, you press the call button and it comes over.
- The crossing takes about 3 minutes, and you can enjoy views from the water—including cranes and docks on the former Uraga shipyard site.
- The current vessel is “Atagomaru,” an FRP (reinforced plastic) boat inspired by Edo-period “gozabune” style. Capacity is 12 passengers plus 1 crew, in service since 1998-08-09.
- The ferry has a long history, believed to date back to around 1725. The route is also known as “Uraga Kaido,” a rare “waterborne city road” (Route No. 2073).

Attention:
- Hours: 07:00–17:00
- Service may be suspended due to rough seas/strong winds or during vessel inspections (sometimes operated flexibly—check before you go).
- Parking: None
- Accessibility (barrier-free): Not equipped with elevators/escalators/ramps; wheelchair-accessible toilets and wheelchair rental are not available.
- Fares (one-way):
- Adult: 400 JPY
- Elementary & Junior High: 200 JPY
- Preschool child: Free (1 per adult; additional children charged at the student fare)
- Under 1 year: Free
- Bicycle, etc.: 50 JPY
- Strollers & pets: Free
- Large luggage that uses a seat: 50 JPY
- Disability discount available; Yokosuka residents pay half price.

Link:

Title: Uraga Dock (Uraga Brick Dry Dock) — Limited-Visit Industrial Heritage Spot

Datetime:
- Report snapshot: 2025-12-26 19:31 (JST)

Place:
- Uraga 4-7, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan
- Area: Hashirimizu / Kannonzaki / Otsu / Uraga
- Access: About a 10-minute walk from Keikyu Uraga Station

Detail:
- When you go down the stairs at Uraga Station, you can see large shipyard-era buildings and cranes (some parts have been dismantled). This site is the former Sumitomo Heavy Industries Uraga shipyard, where shipbuilding continued for more than a century and produced about 1,000 vessels.
- Until the site closed in 2003, ships such as Nippon Maru, Kaiwo Maru, Seikan ferry boats, and escort ships were built here, and the town was lively with shipyard workers.
- The brick dry dock (built in 1899) is the only place in Japan where you can see this type of brick dry dock.
- In 2021, the area including the dock was donated from Sumitomo Heavy Industries to Yokosuka City.
- Background (history overview): Shipbuilding in Uraga dates back to 1854, and the company that later became known as “Uraga Dock” was established in 1897; the dry dock was completed two years later, and the yard went through multiple name changes before closing in 2003.

Attention:
- Uraga Dock can be visited **only on designated public-opening days** (events or limited tours).
- Accessibility is limited: elevators, escalators, step-free entrance measures, accessible toilets, wheelchair rental, baby changing facilities, and accessible parking are listed as not available.
- Viewing routes and what you can enter may vary by the tour/event; in some cases, structures can be viewed from outside the site.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/uragadock.html
- https://www.wakuwaku-yokosuka.jp/uragarengadock.php

Title: Awashima Shrine (Awashima Jinja)

Datetime:
- Annual ritual festival: March 3 (Hinamatsuri / Peach Festival). Source page captured: 2025-12-26 19:03 (JST).

Place:
- 1-18-29 Ashina, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan (Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama area).

Detail:
- Awashima Shrine is said to have been enshrined here from Awashima Shrine in Kada (present-day Kada, Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture). It has long been worshiped across the Miura Peninsula since at least the Edo period, especially as a shrine for matchmaking and safe voyages.
- A well-known local rite is to dedicate a *bottomless ladle* (a ladle with the bottom removed) tied with hemp. This custom expresses prayers for safe childbirth—“as water drains out, may the birth go smoothly”—and is held on March 3.
- During the festival, Shinto priests and shrine maidens board a boat from Ashina Beach in front of the shrine and perform a “floating hina dolls” ritual (nagashi-bina).
- The west coast area of Yokosuka has several related spots connected with safe childbirth and matchmaking, such as Junisho Shrine and Akiya’s “Kosan-ishi” (Childbirth Stone).
- Access (public transit): From Keikyu Shin-Zushi Station, take a bus toward Nagai (e.g., bound for Yokosuka City Hospital or Nagai; about 25 minutes). Get off at “Ashina” bus stop, then walk about 15 minutes.

Attention:
- No parking available on site.
- Barrier-free facilities are limited (e.g., no elevators/escalators, no wheelchair-accessible toilets). Wheelchair users can worship in front of the main hall, but entry into the hall is not permitted.
- Contact: Yokosuka Tourist Information Office (Tel: +81-46-822-8301, 09:30–17:00).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/awashima-z.html

Tags: yokosuka, kanagawa, shrine, history-and-culture, matchmaking, safe-childbirth, maritime-safety, hinamatsuri, floating-hina-dolls

Detail:
- Kumano Shrine is the principal guardian shrine of the entire Nagai area and is affectionately called “Gongensama” by locals.
- Tradition says it was founded in the Kenkyu era (1190–1199), when Ienaga (the eldest son of Suzuki Shigeie, a retainer of Minamoto no Yoshitsune) enshrined Kumano Gongen from Kishu (his hometown) at this site.
- A monument beside the stone stairway records the names of fish and dried-fish wholesalers from Nihonbashi (Edo) who donated to create the steps, hinting at the Kumano faith among fishing communities and historical ties between Nagai and Edo.

Attention:

Title: Tomyodo Lighthouse (燈明堂)

Datetime:
- Source page captured: 2025-12-26 20:39 (JST)

Place:
- Nishi-Uraga 6, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan

Detail:
- Tomyodo Lighthouse stands on the west side of Uraga Port and historically served as a navigation light for ships entering and leaving the harbor. It was built in 1648 by order of the shogunate, and its rapeseed-oil lamp was said to be visible up to about 4 nautical miles (7.4 km) offshore.
- From the Genroku era onward, it was maintained at the expense of East Uraga's dried-sardine (hoshi-iwashi) wholesalers. It reportedly operated every day for about 220 years, protecting the shipping route until it was abolished in 1872.
- The original structure remained into the 1880s but later collapsed due to weather, leaving only the stone base. In 1988, the current building was reconstructed on the remaining stonework to match the historical exterior.
- A small sandy beach stretches from Tomyodo, and you can still see many vessels passing offshore today.
- Admission: Free.
- Access: From Keikyu Uraga Station, take a bus bound for Keikyu Kurihama Station via Chiyogasaki (about 8 minutes). Get off at “Tomyodo Iriguchi” bus stop, then walk about 5 minutes.
- Parking: Nearby “Tomyodo Green Space” parking is available.
- Contact: Yokosuka Tourist Information Center (Tel: +81-46-822-8301, 9:30–17:00).

Attention:
- Accessibility (barrier-free): Not well equipped. No elevator or escalator, and no slope/step-free entrance measures are listed. No accessible toilet, no ostomate toilet, no wheelchair rental, no diaper-changing sheet, and no universal (adult) changing sheet. There is one dedicated parking space for people with disabilities, but no guidance blocks are listed.
- If you need step-free access or accessible restrooms, plan accordingly and consider checking the latest conditions before visiting.

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/toumyoudou.html

Title: Mt. Houdaiyama (Gun Battery Ruins) — Hiking Spot in Yokosuka

- Area: Akiya / Sajima / Takeyama, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa, Japan

Detail:
- Houdaiyama is the nickname for Otsukayama along the hiking course that runs from Miura Fuji to Mt. Takeyama. It became known as “Houdaiyama” because the Imperial Japanese Navy built a gun battery here in the early Shōwa period.
- At the summit, there is the Japan Coast Guard’s Takeyama Receiving Station, enclosed by fencing, with prominent parabolic antennas.
- Next to the facility, a well-preserved, mortar-bowl-shaped gun emplacement (battery remains) can still be seen. A high-angle gun was once installed at the center.
- Eight square openings on the side are thought to have been ammunition storage spaces.

Attention:
- Access is a long walk (about 80 minutes on foot from Keikyū Nagasawa Station).
- No parking is available.
- Accessibility/barrier-free features are not provided (no elevator/escalator/ramps; wheelchair-accessible facilities are not available).
- Water facilities are at the Mt. Takeyama summit restroom (not at Houdaiyama itself), so plan water and restroom breaks accordingly.

Title: Ruins of Kinugasa Castle (Kinugasa-jōshi)

Datetime:
- 2025-12-26 19:57 JST

Place:
- Kinugasa area, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (near the Kinugasa IC entrance on the Yokohama–Yokosuka Road)

Detail:
- A historic hilltop/medieval mountain-castle site that once served as the main stronghold of the **Miura clan**, a powerful local family on the Miura Peninsula from the late Heian to early Kamakura periods.
- The fortress was a **natural-terrain castle** (no stone walls or moats like later castles). Rivers such as the **Miyama River** and **Ōyato River** are thought to have functioned as natural defensive lines.
- The site is closely tied to the **Battle of Kinugasa (1180)**, when a much larger Taira (Heike) force attacked the Miura defenders—an episode connected to the opening era of the Kamakura period.
- Today it is mainly enjoyed as a **short historical hike / walk**, with points of interest including:
- **“Uma-kaeshi no Saka” (Horse-turning Slope):** a notably steep ascent on the route toward the main area.
- **Fudō Waterfall (Fudō no Taki):** a spring/water spot below Daizen-ji, linked to a local legend and considered important for daily and defensive water use.
- **Momiiwa (Lookout Rock):** a large boulder said to have been used to observe and direct the battle; artifacts were reportedly found nearby during early 20th‑century site works.
- **Yatake bamboo (arrow bamboo):** bamboo historically used as arrow material; the surrounding “Yabe” place-name is associated with arrow-making traditions.
- **Seki Jizō (Cough Jizō):** a small Jizō statue tied to a story from the battle; locally associated with relief from coughs.
- **Karamete-guchi (rear gate route):** a narrow cut-through path said to have been heavily defended; nearby are traces of earthworks, training-ground areas, and old wells.

Attention:
- **No parking available.**
- The route inside the historic area is **unpaved** and includes **steep slopes and stairs**—wear shoes with good grip and allow extra time.
- Barrier-free facilities are essentially **not available** (e.g., no elevators/escalators; no wheelchair-accessible toilets or rentals). Plan accordingly.
- For official guidance, contact the **Yokosuka City Tourist Information Office**: +81-46-822-8301 (9:30–17:00).

Link:
- https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/kinugasa-zyoushi.html

Tags: Yokosuka, Kinugasa, Castle ruins, Miura clan, Kamakura period, Heian period, History & culture, Hiking / walking trail, Battle site, Scenic lookout

Title: West Kano Shrine (Nishi Kano Jinja) — Uraga, Yokosuka (Kanagawa, Japan)

Datetime:
- 12/26/25, 8:39 PM (page capture timestamp)

Place:
- West Kano Shrine (Nishi Kano Jinja)
- Address: 1-1-13 Nishi-Uraga, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-0824, Japan

Detail:
- **Overview / origin:** The shrine is associated with the title “Kano Myojin” (“the deity that grants wishes”). Tradition says the monk Mongaku prayed for the revival of the Minamoto clan by enshrining (inviting) the spirit of Iwashimizu Hachimangu; after the wish was fulfilled, the shrine received the title “Kano Myojin.” It is said to have begun in 1181, and the enshrined deity is Emperor Ojin (as with Iwashimizu Hachimangu).
- **Architecture & craftsmanship:** The current shrine building was rebuilt in 1842 (after a loss in 1837). A major highlight is the extremely elaborate interior decoration, including more than 230 carvings around the shrine precincts, attributed to the Awa sculptor Goto Rihei. Look for the coffered ceiling carvings of flowers and birds (including motifs believed not to have existed in Japan at the time), and try to find the hidden wrestler figure said to be supporting a ridgepost.
- **Komainu (guardian dogs):** The komainu in front of the shrine appear to have open mouths on both sides. There is also a “hidden” cute komainu—partly concealed near a pillar—so keep an eye out.
- **Plaster relief art (Kote-e):** At the entrance of the shrine office, there is a white relief decoration made with trowel-and-plaster technique (“kote-e”). It is said to be a work from 1930 (Showa 5) by Ishikawa Zenkichi, a nationally known master of plaster craft (“Miura no Zenkichi”).
- **Power-spot style visit:** The shrine is popular as a “wish-granting” spot. A local practice says that if you place West Kano Shrine’s magatama (comma-shaped jewel) into the amulet pouch from East Kano Shrine and carry it with you, it may help bring good relationships (including romance). The East and West Kano Shrines are connected by the “Uraga no Watashi” ferry that crosses Uraga harbor.
- **Festival culture:** A tiger dance (Tora Odori), designated as an intangible folk cultural property, is offered at the annual festival in September and is said to have been passed down locally since 1720.
- **Nearby historical notes:** A monument commemorates Emperor Meiji resting here on May 18, 1881, when he came to observe the construction progress of the Kannonzaki battery.

Attention:
- **Hours:** 8:30–17:00 (worship/prayer is possible all day). No regular closing days.
- **Access by transit:** From Keikyu Uraga Station, take a bus toward Kurihama Station (~5 min), get off at “Konyamachi,” then walk ~1 minute.
- **Accessibility:** The site information indicates no elevator/escalator and no ramp/step-free entrance measures. There is no wheelchair-accessible toilet or wheelchair rental listed. The route from Konyamachi bus stop includes stairs.
- **Suggested itinerary:** If you want to try the magatama + amulet tradition, plan to visit both West and East Kano Shrines and use the Uraga ferry connection.

Link:
- Yokosuka tourism page: https://www.cocoyoko.net/spot/nishi-kanou-z.html
- Official site: https://kanoujinjya.jp/
